title: ULA ready to roll Atlas 5 rocket to launch pad today
summary: United Launch Alliance teams at Cape Canaveral are preparing to roll an Atlas 5 rocket to its launch pad Wednesday, moving the launcher into position for liftoff Thursday evening with a pair of geostationary satellites for the U.S. Space Force.

title: SpaceX, ULA targeting back-to-back geostationary launches
summary: SpaceX and competitor United Launch Alliance (ULA) are on track to launch their Falcon 9 and Atlas V rockets less than 25...

title: Space Force acquisition chief to meet with ULA and Blue Origin, expects Vulcan to launch in December
summary: Frank Calvelli said he wants to make sure Blue Origin and ULA understand 'the importance of hitting their milestones' for the BE-4 and Vulcan

title: Virgin Orbit ready for first night launch
summary: Virgin Orbit says it’s ready for a nighttime launch for the U.S. Space Force as it attempts to get into a more frequent rhythm of building and launching vehicles.

title: NASA aims to launch the SLS rocket in just 2 months
CubeSat launches on scouting mission for NASA’s Artemis moon program
summary: NASA’s $30 million CAPSTONE mission lifted off Tuesday on a Rocket Lab launcher from New Zealand, departing Earth on a circuitous but fuel-efficient four-month journey toward a halo orbit around the moon to test technologies and operations for the Artemis moon program.

title: Ovzon needs to piggyback another Ariane 5 ride for late 2022 launch
summary: Arianespace is looking to move Ovzon’s first satellite to another Ariane 5 after Eutelsat switched to a dedicated mission to launch sooner.

title: Help NASA Scientists Find Clouds on Mars
summary: By identifying clouds in data collected by NASA’s Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, the public can increase scientists’ understanding of the Red Planet’s atmosphere.

title: Chinese commercial launch firm Expace raises $237 million
summary: Chinese launch service provider Expace has secured $237 million in B round funding, following last week's return to flight of its Kuaizhou-1A solid rocket.

title: Northrop Grumman’s Cygnus supply ship departs space station
summary: A commercial Cygnus supply ship from Northrop Grumman departed the International Space Station Tuesday, completing a four-month stay after delivering more than 8,000 pounds of cargo and boosting the research lab into a slightly higher orbit. The Cygnus spacecraft was expected to deploy a CubeSat before heading for a destructive re-entry.
